text: (upbeat music)
- Aaron, thanks for joining us today.
I just realized it's been exactly one year
since we spoke about how we kickstart

into what both our

about your current role
and how you got here?
- So for almost 50 years now,
Bridgewater has systematically invested
in markets across the globe based
on our fundamental understanding

of what drives those
markets and economies.
We've then programmed that understanding
into what we call an expert system
or what everyone calls an expert system,

which every day pulls data
from the outside world,

runs it through the logic
that we've programmed in
and outputs positions on markets.

All of those positions
are still fundamental,
not high frequency or something like that.
Then about a year ago, Greg Jensen,
who's one of our co-CIOs at Bridgewater
and has been heavily involved in AI and ML

for over a decade now,
decided that it was time

to assemble an interdisciplinary
team of investors,

data scientists, machine
learning engineers

and technologists to
basically rethink our process
and to create an AI, ML first process
for generating investment logic

that is also capable of
improving itself over time.
That's what we're calling
the artificial investment associate.

And so my responsibility
within that as the CTO
is for shaping the technical vision

and strategy working with
those other partners.

I mean, amazing charter,
especially the pivot into like AI enabled,

I mean, technology to

almost 10 years now,
Bridgewater has been partnering

So that whole process that

churns through a lot of data

and requires a lot of

And that's all in S3, EKS

And the architecture,

and we're implementing for AYA
is not wholly new.

We're keeping a lot of
the tabular concepts

and the deep connection to
data to test our hypotheses.
That's all staying the same.
What we're doing is we're introducing

the capabilities of
these foundational models
to actually reason and create hypotheses.

And so we're marrying both
the fundamental understanding
and the systematic in order to create

what we think is going to
be a very powerful system
that can self-loop and self-teach.

Can you share more?
You talked about foundational models.
Can you share more how your,

our investment process,
we think that these foundational models

have a place in almost every
step of our research circle.

we're trying to stretch them

we're also very impressed

with how well it can perform

If you give it the right

it will give you a pretty good answer.
Where the foundational models,
the first challenge that we found

And of course, in order to compete

we have to do something
that's more than simple.

We need to be able to

Bedrock is a great

There's other benefits that

But first and foremost,
what's most important to us

is that we're getting the
best models available to AYA

So the LLaMA series, Cohere,

which is even more impressive than before.
- Aaron, your point on how the best model

for the right task

One of the major fundamental thesis
that drove Bedrock as its design

that customers wanted the

Which models did you choose?

- Sure.

To start, we just started
with the best model,
which was Claude for general reasoning.
And then what we've done over time
is I've created basically an interface.

So this is another thing
that I'll go into quickly

is that another thing that
we've learned over the past year
is that the best prompt engineers
are actually the people who are trying
to get the most value out of the product.
And so it's not someone on the tech team

that is gonna be the best
prompt engineer for us.

The best prompt engineers
are actually our investors.

for them to iterate and

together a series of calls

actually achieve the goal.

they can tell the difference very quickly.

And so we started with

that was the most generally capable.

And then over time,
we've added other models.

What we've done is we've
found that sometimes

the quick model is the

Sometimes the slower and more expensive

You'll need to, you'll

That's pretty rare.

the best foundational models

instead of our own fine
tunes for most use cases.

that this is just the

- So it is like using a

weight of questions

Is that kind of how I

there wasn't an answer

So you'd RAG it all you want,

you're gonna get some things

It's still not out the door good for us,

for our analysts to then
use that as the first draft.
- I do have one question.
I said meet, I mean, part of my role,

I end up meeting a lot
of actually customers

way further along in that journey

what advice would you give

- There's a lot of learnings
that I had over the past year.

So I don't know if I'll get
them all out, but I'll try.

So the first thing is be clear
about what your value-add is.

Why can't clod out of the box
address your users' problems?
Why can't perplexity out of the box
address your users' problems?

Once you know that,
create an infrastructure,

create a platform that
expects most of the components
to change over time.

Things are just moving so
fast that you have to build
in order to slot in the next best model

or the next best API
or whatever it may be.
So that's number two.
Number three is what I alluded to earlier

of likely the best
prompt engineers for you

are your subject matter
experts, so your end users.

I do think that surfacing
the knobs to the end users
is actually pretty powerful in many cases,

and you'll be surprised
about how much faster
the capabilities or the use cases evolve

if you're able to bring users
in close to that process.

So I would say those are the
three most important things
that if I were to start over,
I would have those top of mind.
- That's fascinating.
You're saying, hey, one, the value-add
should be more than just a model,

and it's not just about
even having one model.
It can be a chain of models.
And third, which is not obvious,
I don't think, to everyone,

and iterate on what is the
best customer experience.

It's not obvious because
they usually are viewed

as one-step remote, especially
for some of these use cases.

is that it's natural language,

It's not even English.

my responses were bad
